title: Kommunistka
text:
Kommunistka (in ) was a communist magazine from the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>, associated to the <a href="Zhenotdel">Zhenotdel</a>, founded by <a href="Inessa%20Armand">Inessa Armand</a> and <a href="Alexandra%20Kollontai">Alexandra Kollontai</a> in 1920.
"Kommunistka" was published on a monthly basis. The magazine was targeted specially to <a href="Underclass">lower class</a> women, and explored the way to achieve <a href="women%27s%20emancipation">women's emancipation</a>, not only in a theoretical manner, but practical, as the <a href="russian%20revolution">revolution</a> by itself would not solve the women's <a href="gender%20inequality">inequality</a> and oppression in the family and society. Armand and Kollontai insisted in the low percentage of women in the public sphere –in the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20the%20Soviet%20Union">party</a>, in business management, in the <a href="soviet">soviet</a>s, in the <a href="trade%20union">trade union</a>s or in the government– which would require a specific work for liberation.
Armand, Kollontai or <a href="Krupskaya">Krupskaya</a> addressed issues such as <a href="sexuality">sexuality</a>, <a href="abortion">abortion</a>, marriage and <a href="divorce">divorce</a>, the relationship between sexes, <a href="free%20love">free love</a>, morality, family, motherhood or the liberation of women from the slavery of men. Furthermore, the magazine's perspective emphasized that women liberation was intimately linked to the emancipation of the whole <a href="communist%20society">communist society</a>.
The magazine disappeared in 1930 together with the <a href="Zhenotdel">Zhenotdel</a> itself under the <a href="Stalinist">Stalinist</a> mandate.
